brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a JetBrains inspection rule that checks for incorrectly defined persistent object classes in Java Persistence API (JPA). The rule flags classes that are not top-level, are final, are annotated multiple times, or are defined as both a persistent entity and an entity listener.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'persistent-object-class-signature-checks' checks all classes in the project that are not part of a library. It asserts that a class is not final, is not annotated multiple times, and is not defined as both a persistent entity and an entity listener. If any of these conditions are not met, a message is generated with the fully qualified name of the class and a description of the issue.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/jpa-entity-listeners
Summary: This page provides a comprehensive guide on JPA Entity Listeners, which are used for listening to entity lifecycle events. It explains how to define and use them, which is relevant to the rule that checks if a class is defined as both a persistent entity and an entity listener.

2. URL: https://www.javaworld.com/article/3379043/what-is-jpa-introduction-to-the-java-persistence-api.html
Summary: This page provides an introduction to the Java Persistence API (JPA), explaining its purpose, how it works, and how to use it. It is relevant to the rule as it provides context and background information on JPA, which the rule is designed to work with.
